newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Hebron talks continue under shadow of bombings.
newsitem.headline: Hebron talks continue under shadow of bombings.

text.p: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and U.S. peace negotiator Dennis Ross held further talks on a Hebron deal under the shadow of Tel Aviv bombings that wounded 13 people.
Army Radio said the session ended in the early hours of Friday without any breakthrough.
Israeli police said they believed that Arabs planted the nail-packed bombs that blew up in trash bins near Tel Aviv's central bus station on Thursday.
Netanyahu, visiting the wounded in hospital, pledged to respond with "extreme severity" if it emerged the bombers came from Palestinian self-rule areas.

No one immediately claimed responsibility for the blasts, a week after an off-duty Israeli soldier shot into a crowd of Palestinians in the West Bank town of Hebron, wounding seven Arabs. Militant Moslem groups vowed to avenge the attack.

The bombs exploded several kilometres (miles) from Netanyahu's Tel Aviv office while he met Ross, struggling to end an Israel-PLO impasse over a deal on Israeli troop redeployment from Hebron and dates for further pullbacks in the West Bank.
"We raised various ideas but the conversation was cut off by the attack and for this reason I have nothing to announce to you," Netanyahu told reporters at Tel Aviv's Ichilov hospital.
Netanyahu and Ross resumed their meeting later, a sign that Israel was taking no action for now to slow or stop diplomatic efforts to clinch a Hebron deal.
Palestinian President Yasser Arafat was waiting for the outcome of Ross's meeting with Netanyahu to determine whether he should leave for a European trip on Friday, PLO officials said.
At the hospital, the right-wing Netanyahu held out the possibility of a stronger Israeli response to the blasts.

"According to all the signs, it appears to be a terrorist attack," he said. "If it becomes clear that the terrorists who carried out this attack came from the Palestinian Authority (area), we will respond with extreme severity."

Asked if the bombings would affect the Hebron talks, which have dragged on for months, Netanyahu said: "We will wage the battle against the terrorists and we will also check if these terrorists came from the area of the Palestinian Authority.
"(If they did), it should not be automatically assumed that we will carry on," he said, referring to peace negotiations with the PLO.
Asked about Netanyahu's comments, Marwan Kanafani, a spokesman for Arafat, told Reuters: "Netanyahu is saying that all the time. I'm not going to take him seriously this time."

Earlier, Palestinians turned down a U.S. compromise date for Israeli troop withdrawals in the West Bank, insisting Washington make Israel respect the original timetable under which the three pullbacks should be completed by September.
"Israel has proposed to end the last stage of further redeployments from the rest of the West Bank in 1999. We rejected that," said Tayeb Abdel-Rahim, general secretary of the Palestinian presidency.
"So to break the deadlock in the talks Ross proposed as a compromise mid-1998, and we rejected this as well," he said.
National Police Chief Assaf Hefetz said the Tel Aviv bombs blew up 10 minutes and several metres (yards) apart. One Arab suspect was arrested, police said.
A spokeswoman for Ichilov hospital said 10 people were hurt, none seriously. An ambulance service said three other people who were slightly wounded were taken to another hospital.
Palestinian militants last mounted a bombing campaign in Israel in February and March last year when suicide bombers killed 59 people.
